author: Legal Correspondent
text:
Petition says they have allegedly termed execution of Guru a “judicial killing”

A ‘People For Nation March for Unity to Save the Country’ taking out a march Raj Ghat to Jantar Mantar on Sunday in protest against the recent incidents at the JNU.— Photo: R.V. Moorthy

The Supreme Court has agreed to hear a plea to initiate contempt of court proceedings against jailed JNU students’ union president Kanhaiya Kumar, former Delhi University lecturer S.A.R Geelani and some others for allegedly terming the execution of Parliament attack case convict Afzal Guru a “judicial killing.”

A Bench led by Chief Justice of India T.S. Thakur on Friday agreed to hear the petition filed by lawyer Vineet Dhanda, contending that the term “judicial killing” was in contempt of the apex court verdict pronounced on August 4, 2005, handing down death penalty to Guru for being a part of the conspiracy in the attack on Parliament in 2001.
title: SC to hear contempt plea against Kanhaiya, Geelani
